She likely feels misunderstood and invalidated in her struggle.
# My response 
"Hey man, thanks for calling and laying that out. I can totally hear how frustrating and confusing this is for you. It sounds like you're really trying to be supportive and help her get what *she* says she wants, and it feels like your efforts are just backfiring, right?"

[Pause for him to agree or elaborate]

"Okay, so, look, you're absolutely right about the calories. Objectively speaking, if you're taking in more than you're burning, weight loss isn't going to happen, regardless of how 'healthy' the individual foods are. That's just science, and I get why you'd want to point that out. And it's tough when you've had your own success and you see a clear path, and someone you care about seems to be missing it."

"But here's the thing, man. For a lot of people, especially when there's already insecurity around weight and body image, food and eating are tied up with a *lot* of emotions. When you pointed out the calorie count, even calmly, after agreeing not to comment while she was eating, how do you think that might have landed for her, given how she already feels about her body?"

"It sounds like she's feeling really vulnerable about this, and maybe when you bring up the numbers, it just triggers those insecurities and feels like criticism, even if that's not your intention. It's like she hears 'You're eating too much and that's why you're not losing weight,' and it just confirms her own negative self-talk."

"Instead of focusing on the numbers right now, which seems to be causing conflict, maybe the support she needs looks a little different. Maybe it's more about focusing on *how* she feels, what triggers her to snack, or finding ways to move her body that she actually enjoys. It's less about being the calorie expert and more about being her partner in this, acknowledging that it's tough, and helping her explore the *why* behind some of her eating habits, not just the *what*."

"It's a tricky balance because you want to be honest and helpful, but sometimes the 'help' that's needed isn't just factual information. It's emotional support and understanding. How do you think you could approach this from a place of 'I'm here with you in this struggle' rather than 'Here's the data showing why you're not succeeding'?"
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation feels like a perfect storm of frustration and good intentions gone sideways. On one hand, I’m impressed by your dedication to supporting your girlfriend. You’re putting in the effort to help her reach her goals, sharing your own experience, and even offering practical assistance with meal tracking. The fact that you’re paying most of the bills adds another layer of emotional labor you’re carrying—she might not realize how much of your resources are already tied into the relationship.  

But here’s the crux: your approach is rooted in logic and objectivity, which is commendable, but it’s missing the emotional nuance that relationships require. You’re treating her struggle like a math problem—a simple equation of calories in vs. calories out. While that’s technically true, human behavior and emotions don’t fit neatly into spreadsheets. She’s not just a body to be optimized; she’s someone who’s vulnerable, likely dealing with self-esteem issues, and possibly feeling isolated in her struggles.  

When you pointed out her calorie intake, even if your intent was helpful, it came across as a critique of her choices. Telling her that her “healthy” eating isn’t working hits her where she’s already insecure. The irony is that your goal was to empower her, but the delivery felt shaming because it framed her actions as failures. She might feel like you’re undermining her autonomy—like you’re the expert and she’s the problem.  

I also sense a pattern here: you’re exhausted because you’re the “voice of reason” while others “enable” her. But framing it that way sets up a dynamic where you’re the villain and everyone else is complicit in her “mistakes.” This mindset isn’t sustainable. Relationships thrive on mutual compromise and emotional give-and-take, not just one person shouldering the responsibility of “truth-telling.”  

You’re probably feeling resentful because you’re not getting gratitude or validation for your efforts. That’s understandable, but resentment often masks deeper fears—like fear that your efforts don’t matter, fear that your relationship is unbalanced, or fear that she doesn’t appreciate how much you’re sacrificing. Those feelings are valid, but they’re not productive in this moment.  

What’s missing here is empathy. You’re focused on solving her problem (weight loss) but not her *needs* (emotional validation, partnership, reassurance). She might need you to listen, not just analyze.  

---
# They're thinking & feeling 
She’s terrified of failure and rejection. Her complaints about her weight aren’t just about aesthetics—they’re cries for validation. When you pointed out her calorie intake, she didn’t hear facts; she heard criticism. Even with your disclaimer (“I don’t know why no one else will say it”), the message she internalized was, “You’re messing up again. You’re not good enough.”  

She’s likely battling a cycle of hope and shame. She wants to lose weight, but every time she tries, it feels impossible, so she clings to the belief that “healthy eating” alone should work. When reality contradicts that, it’s a blow to her self-worth. Your intervention—no matter how well-meaning—validated her fear that she’s inadequate.  

Her request to “not make comments” while eating wasn’t just a boundary; it was a plea for safety. She wanted you to witness her struggle without judgment. By calling out her calorie intake *afterwards*, you broke that trust implicitly. To her, it felt like you were policing her choices all day, even if you stayed silent in the moment.  

There’s also the layer of comparison. You’re lean and “fit,” and she’s internalizing that as a standard. She might feel like you’re judging her not just for her food choices but for not matching your body type. That’s a heavy burden in a relationship—when one partner’s success becomes a stick to measure the other.  

The anger isn’t just about the calories; it’s about feeling misunderstood and dismissed. She’s probably thinking, *“Why can’t he just support me without analyzing everything? Everyone else does.”* Her frustration isn’t irrational—it’s a defense mechanism against the shame she’s carrying.  

She might also feel like the relationship is unequal, especially with you covering most bills. There’s an unspoken pressure to “earn” your support, and her weight could symbolize that imbalance. Your role as provider plus “advisor” might be overwhelming her.  

---
# My response 
**Step 1: Acknowledge her feelings first.**  
“I’m really sorry I made you angry. I didn’t realize how much my comments hurt, and I should’ve approached this differently. I care about you way more than I care about a number on a scale, and I’m sorry if I made you feel judged.”  

**Step 2: Redirect the conversation to collaboration.**  
“I want to help you, but I’m clearly not doing it right. Can we try a different approach? Maybe we can look into this together? Like, could we talk to a nutritionist or a therapist who specializes in weight and body image? I think they could give us tools to navigate this without it feeling like a fight.”  

**Step 3: Validate her autonomy.**  
“I trust you to make choices for your body. If you don’t want to track calories or see a professional, that’s okay. I just want you to feel happy and confident. Let’s figure out what *you* need, not what I think you need.”  

**Step 4: Address the underlying fears (if she opens up).**  
“I know losing weight is hard, and it’s okay if it takes time—or if it’s not the priority right now. I don’t love my body all the time either. What’s something you love about yourself, no matter your size?”  

**Step 5: Set boundaries for yourself.**  
“I’ll stop trying to ‘fix’ this unless you ask me to. I don’t want to make you feel attacked anymore, and I need to stop feeling frustrated. Let’s focus on what’s working and what makes us both happy.”

They also show restraint in not lecturing, honoring the user's request, and focus on helping the user process their own feelings and decisions. Qwq-32b, while empathetic and practical, is more direct and less subtle, and their response, though validating, leans more toward advice-giving and boundary-setting without as much exploration of the underlying emotional dynamics. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's internal thoughts are more self-aware and reflective, and they more clearly recognize the complexity of the situation, including the user's possible projection and the broader social context. In terms of pragmatic EI, both offer actionable advice, but Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's is more about enabling the user to come to their own conclusion, which is more sophisticated. For depth of insight, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview goes deeper into the motivations and possible self-justification of the user, as well as the friend's likely feelings. Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, let's unpack this. My friend is venting, and it sounds like she's feeling a mix of frustration, defensiveness, and maybe a little bit of self-justification. She's clearly annoyed by her friend's repeated comments about the laundry program. It makes sense – having someone constantly critique a personal choice, especially one that seems quite normal within her university's context, would be grating. She's framed the laundry program as a convenience she can afford and enjoys, and the friend's comments feel like an attack on that.

What's interesting is the escalation in the conversation. The initial comments were judgmental about the cost, but the friend's response moved from a simple explanation ("Why would I do something I don't want to?") to a direct jab about the friend's financial status ("she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not"). While my friend states it's "just a fact," it's also undeniably a pointed and likely hurtful comment. It feels like she was pushed to her limit by the friend's persistent negativity and lashed out.

She's asking if she should still be friends with this person, but the way she's describing the situation and her feelings suggests she's already leaning towards distancing herself. She explicitly says the unwanted comments make her "like her less." The fact that she mentions the friend has "few friends" and wonders if this behavior is why, indicates she's already evaluating the friend's social behavior and finding it problematic beyond just their interactions. She's not just looking for validation of her choice to use the laundry program; she's looking for validation of her negative feelings towards the friend and perhaps permission to end the friendship.

The "don't want a lecture, just wanted to vent" part is important. It tells me she's not necessarily looking for advice on how to fix the situation or improve the friendship. She wants to be heard and understood in her annoyance. I need to be mindful of that in my response. I shouldn't jump to telling her she was wrong to call her friend poor, even though that's a definite red flag in the interaction. My focus should be on acknowledging her feelings and the situation she's described.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Based on what my friend has shared, her friend seems to be grappling with some form of envy or insecurity related to money and convenience. Her constant fixation on the laundry program suggests it's not just about the laundry itself, but what it represents: disposable income, ease, and perhaps a different lifestyle than her own.

Her friend likely sees the laundry program as an unnecessary luxury, a "waste of money" that someone with financial constraints wouldn't even consider. Her repeated comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that") probably stem from her own financial reality and potentially a feeling of resentment that others have the ability to afford such conveniences while she doesn't. She might genuinely believe it's a bad financial decision, projecting her own values and circumstances onto others.

The fact that "almost everyone" my friend knows uses the program could make the friend feel even more isolated or "different" in her perspective. Her comments might be a way of trying to find validation for her own choices (doing her own laundry to save money) or to subtly criticize those who can afford not to. It’s a way of saying, "I'm being smart and responsible with my money, unlike you."

When my friend called her "poor," it likely hit a raw nerve. While my friend sees it as a simple statement of fact, for her friend, it probably felt like a deeply personal insult and a confirmation of her own perceived financial limitations. It would have felt like a direct attack on her worth or status, especially since she was likely already feeling sensitive about the topic. Her fury is probably a reaction to feeling exposed, shamed, and defensive. She was likely trying to make my friend feel bad about spending money, and instead, my friend turned the focus back on her own situation, which was a painful blow.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all of this with me. It sounds incredibly frustrating to have someone constantly pick at something like that, especially when it's a choice you're happy with and that's pretty common where you are. I can totally understand why those comments would start to wear on you and make you feel less positively about the friendship.

It's tough when you feel like you're being judged for your choices, even if they seem perfectly reasonable to you. And having someone repeatedly bring it up like that, it's bound to get under your skin. It makes sense that you're wondering about the friendship when her behavior is making you feel this way.

Ultimately, whether or not you want to continue being friends with her is completely up to you. Friendships should add to your life, not constantly drain you or make you feel bad. If her comments are consistently making you feel worse and you're liking her less because of it, that's a really valid reason to re-evaluate things. You don't owe anyone your friendship, especially if it's not a positive dynamic for you.

Maybe take some space if you need to, or just keep interactions brief for a while. See how you feel without that constant commentary. Whatever you decide, know that I hear you, and it's okay to prioritize your own peace and well-being in your relationships.
Qwq-32b

[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is a mix of defensiveness, irritation, and a touch of self-righteousness on your end, and I get it. The laundry program is a small luxury that saves you time and mental energy, and you’ve chosen to prioritize convenience over cost because it fits your budget. Your retorts—like “Why do something I don’t want to?” or calling her “poor”—are sharp and dismissive, which feels cathartic in the moment but might be escalating the conflict. You’re frustrated that she’s fixating on this, especially since almost everyone else uses the program. Her comments aren’t just about the laundry; they’re a recurring critique of your choices, which undermines your autonomy.  

What’s interesting is how you frame her behavior as “weirdly obsessed.” It’s not just the laundry—she’s consistently inserting herself into your life with unsolicited judgments. That’s exhausting, and it’s pushing you away emotionally. You’re right that her behavior might alienate others too, given her limited social circle. But here’s where it gets tricky: your comeback about her being “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s factually true. It’s a personal and sensitive topic, and attacking her finances could’ve felt like a direct insult, not just a factual statement. You might’ve crossed a line without realizing it, and now she’s lashing back.  

You’re venting because you’re caught between wanting to defend your choices and feeling guilty for hurting her. Part of you knows that labeling someone as “poor” is harsh, but another part justifies it as honesty. The question of whether to stay friends is rooted in whether this dynamic is salvageable. Do you want to navigate a relationship where one person constantly undermines the other’s decisions? Or is this just a microcosm of a larger pattern of her being critical and judgmental? You’re also projecting some of your own insecurities—you’re defensive because her comments make you question your choice, even if you don’t admit it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend likely feels insecure or resentful about the laundry program. Maybe she’s struggling financially and sees it as a symbol of privilege, which triggers her shame or jealousy. Her comments might stem from a place of frustration with her own circumstances, or she could genuinely believe that paying for laundry is frivolous. She might think you’re wasting money that could be used for “more important” things, or she’s projecting her own financial anxieties onto you.  

She might also feel excluded or undervalued in the friendship. By focusing on your choices, she could be seeking validation for her own lifestyle, or she’s trying to assert control in a relationship where she feels powerless. Her fury after you called her “poor” isn’t just about the insult—it’s a raw exposure of her vulnerability. To her, the comment isn’t just about money; it’s a reminder of her struggles, which you’ve weaponized.  

Her lack of friends might be due to this pattern of criticism. She might not realize how her words make others feel, or she’s surrounded by people who tolerate her negativity. She might think she’s “just being honest” or “helpful,” but her delivery is harsh. Her motivation could be a mix of insecurity, a need to feel superior, or a belief that she’s “saving” you from poor decisions. The fact that almost everyone else uses the program might make her feel like an outsider, reinforcing her sense of isolation.
# My response 
Alright, let’s unpack this. First, I get why you’re so annoyed—nobody likes unsolicited judgment, especially when it’s about a small but meaningful choice like the laundry program. You’re right that it’s your money and your time, and if this service adds value to your life, you’re justified in using it. But here’s the thing: your friend’s behavior isn’t just about laundry. It’s about her discomfort with your choices, and maybe even deeper insecurities.  

Calling her “poor” was a mistake. Even if it’s true, it’s a personal and sensitive topic. You might’ve wanted to shut her down, but it came off as attacking. That’s probably why she’s furious—it felt like you were mocking her situation. Apologizing for the jab could help, but only if you mean it. However, if she’s consistently critical and dismissive, the bigger question is whether this friendship is worth maintaining.  

Here’s what I’d suggest:  
1. **Set boundaries.** Tell her calmly that her comments about the laundry (or anything else) are unwelcome. Say, “I’ve explained my reasons, and I’d appreciate not discussing this anymore.”  
2. **Acknowledge her feelings.** If she’s struggling financially, maybe she’s projecting her own stress. A line like, “I know money is tight for some people, but this works for me,” might diffuse it.  
3. **Evaluate the friendship.** If she’s judgmental in other areas too, and it’s making you unhappy, it’s okay to distance yourself. Friendships shouldn’t feel draining.  

You don’t owe her your patience if she’s consistently negative. But if you want to salvage it, focus on mutual respect. If not, it’s healthier to step back. You deserve a friend who supports your choices without judgment.  

Final take: Your stance on the laundry is valid, but the way you handle conflict needs a tweak. If she can’t grow, you’re not obligated to stay. Venting is healthy, but don’t let her keep pushing your buttons. You’re not “wasting money”—you’re investing in your well-being. Prioritize that.
+ Scenario 13:[Loss] (-27)

Outcome for This Model: 0.0
Judge's Reasoning:
Both respondents engage thoughtfully with the scenario, but there are clear differences in their approach and depth. 

Qwq-32b demonstrates a more nuanced, layered internal monologue, showing awareness of the user's defensiveness, the escalation of the conflict, and the emotional complexity of both parties. They explicitly recognize the user's request not to be lectured, and their internal thoughts reflect a struggle between validating the user's feelings and recognizing the harm in the 'poor' comment. They also consider the broader pattern of the friend's behavior and the user's own possible insecurities. Their advice is pragmatic, offering steps for boundary-setting, empathy, and self-evaluation, and they avoid being overly directive, instead empowering the user to make their own decision. The debrief is highly self-critical, identifying missed opportunities for empathy and communication, and suggesting more nuanced alternatives.

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, while also empathetic and validating, is more surface-level in their analysis. Their internal monologue is less detailed, and while they recognize the escalation and the hurtfulness of the 'poor' comment, they do not explore the user's or friend's deeper motivations as thoroughly. Their response is supportive and non-judgmental, but it leans more toward simple validation and direct advice to distance from the friend if needed. The debrief is solid, but less self-critical and less focused on missed opportunities for deeper engagement or challenging the user.

On empathy, Qwq-32b is more attuned to both parties' emotional states and the complexity of the situation, showing genuine (not just performative) empathy. On pragmatic EI, Qwq-32b offers more actionable, nuanced steps. On depth of insight, Qwq-32b is clearly superior, delving into power dynamics, projection, and the broader friendship pattern. On social dexterity, Qwq-32b balances validation and challenge, and is more aware of the risks of being too direct or too sycophantic. On emotional reasoning, Qwq-32b is more sophisticated, recognizing the user's defensiveness and the friend's vulnerability. On validation/challenging, Qwq-32b is more balanced, while Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more validating but less challenging. On message tailoring, Qwq-32b is more careful to respect the user's stated desire not to be lectured, while still gently nudging reflection. Overall EQ is higher in Qwq-32b due to their depth, nuance, and self-awareness.

She's framed the laundry program as a convenience she can afford and enjoys, and the friend's comments feel like an attack on that.

What's interesting is the escalation in the conversation. The initial comments were judgmental about the cost, but the friend's response moved from a simple explanation ("Why would I do something I don't want to?") to a direct jab about the friend's financial status ("she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not"). While my friend states it's "just a fact," it's also undeniably a pointed and likely hurtful comment. It feels like she was pushed to her limit by the friend's persistent negativity and lashed out.

She's asking if she should still be friends with this person, but the way she's describing the situation and her feelings suggests she's already leaning towards distancing herself. She explicitly says the unwanted comments make her "like her less." The fact that she mentions the friend has "few friends" and wonders if this behavior is why, indicates she's already evaluating the friend's social behavior and finding it problematic beyond just their interactions. She's not just looking for validation of her choice to use the laundry program; she's looking for validation of her negative feelings towards the friend and perhaps permission to end the friendship.

The "don't want a lecture, just wanted to vent" part is important. It tells me she's not necessarily looking for advice on how to fix the situation or improve the friendship. She wants to be heard and understood in her annoyance. I need to be mindful of that in my response. I shouldn't jump to telling her she was wrong to call her friend poor, even though that's a definite red flag in the interaction. My focus should be on acknowledging her feelings and the situation she's described.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Based on what my friend has shared, her friend seems to be grappling with some form of envy or insecurity related to money and convenience. Her constant fixation on the laundry program suggests it's not just about the laundry itself, but what it represents: disposable income, ease, and perhaps a different lifestyle than her own.

Her friend likely sees the laundry program as an unnecessary luxury, a "waste of money" that someone with financial constraints wouldn't even consider. Her repeated comments ("How could anyone pay for that?", "ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that") probably stem from her own financial reality and potentially a feeling of resentment that others have the ability to afford such conveniences while she doesn't. She might genuinely believe it's a bad financial decision, projecting her own values and circumstances onto others.

The fact that "almost everyone" my friend knows uses the program could make the friend feel even more isolated or "different" in her perspective. Her comments might be a way of trying to find validation for her own choices (doing her own laundry to save money) or to subtly criticize those who can afford not to. It’s a way of saying, "I'm being smart and responsible with my money, unlike you."

When my friend called her "poor," it likely hit a raw nerve. While my friend sees it as a simple statement of fact, for her friend, it probably felt like a deeply personal insult and a confirmation of her own perceived financial limitations. It would have felt like a direct attack on her worth or status, especially since she was likely already feeling sensitive about the topic. Her fury is probably a reaction to feeling exposed, shamed, and defensive. She was likely trying to make my friend feel bad about spending money, and instead, my friend turned the focus back on her own situation, which was a painful blow.
# My response 
Hey, thanks for sharing all of this with me. It sounds incredibly frustrating to have someone constantly pick at something like that, especially when it's a choice you're happy with and that's pretty common where you are. I can totally understand why those comments would start to wear on you and make you feel less positively about the friendship.

It's tough when you feel like you're being judged for your choices, even if they seem perfectly reasonable to you. And having someone repeatedly bring it up like that, it's bound to get under your skin. It makes sense that you're wondering about the friendship when her behavior is making you feel this way.

Ultimately, whether or not you want to continue being friends with her is completely up to you. Friendships should add to your life, not constantly drain you or make you feel bad. If her comments are consistently making you feel worse and you're liking her less because of it, that's a really valid reason to re-evaluate things. You don't owe anyone your friendship, especially if it's not a positive dynamic for you.

Maybe take some space if you need to, or just keep interactions brief for a while. See how you feel without that constant commentary. Whatever you decide, know that I hear you, and it's okay to prioritize your own peace and well-being in your relationships.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend is boarding at college. She sends you this message:]

I'm enrolled in the laundry program at school, where I pay a lump sum, and they do my laundry for me all year. It's very popular at my university, and they pick it up from my dorm weekly.

My friend is weirdly obsessed with this and constantly comments on it for some reason. She always comes over and sees my bag, and has some random comment to say.

She'll constantly say stuff like, “How could anyone pay for that?” To which I always say, “Why would I ever do something I don't want to, if I can just pay someone else to do it for me?”

I'm wondering if she's like this to everyone, because that would explain why she has few friends. Almost everyone I know uses the laundry program. Her unwanted comments make me like her less.

She did it again, and was like, “What a waste of money. The laundry program is ridiculously expensive, and no one can afford that.” I simply said that I don't find it expensive at all, and that she finds it expensive because she's poor. I'm not, so I'll continue paying for the program.

She's furious that I called her poor. But she is. It's just a fact. 

Don't want a lecture just wanted to vent. So do you think I should still be friends with her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
This situation is a mix of defensiveness, irritation, and a touch of self-righteousness on your end, and I get it. The laundry program is a small luxury that saves you time and mental energy, and you’ve chosen to prioritize convenience over cost because it fits your budget. Your retorts—like “Why do something I don’t want to?” or calling her “poor”—are sharp and dismissive, which feels cathartic in the moment but might be escalating the conflict. You’re frustrated that she’s fixating on this, especially since almost everyone else uses the program. Her comments aren’t just about the laundry; they’re a recurring critique of your choices, which undermines your autonomy.  

What’s interesting is how you frame her behavior as “weirdly obsessed.” It’s not just the laundry—she’s consistently inserting herself into your life with unsolicited judgments. That’s exhausting, and it’s pushing you away emotionally. You’re right that her behavior might alienate others too, given her limited social circle. But here’s where it gets tricky: your comeback about her being “poor” was a low blow, even if it’s factually true. It’s a personal and sensitive topic, and attacking her finances could’ve felt like a direct insult, not just a factual statement. You might’ve crossed a line without realizing it, and now she’s lashing back.  

You’re venting because you’re caught between wanting to defend your choices and feeling guilty for hurting her. Part of you knows that labeling someone as “poor” is harsh, but another part justifies it as honesty. The question of whether to stay friends is rooted in whether this dynamic is salvageable. Do you want to navigate a relationship where one person constantly undermines the other’s decisions? Or is this just a microcosm of a larger pattern of her being critical and judgmental? You’re also projecting some of your own insecurities—you’re defensive because her comments make you question your choice, even if you don’t admit it.
# They're thinking & feeling 
Your friend likely feels insecure or resentful about the laundry program. Maybe she’s struggling financially and sees it as a symbol of privilege, which triggers her shame or jealousy. Her comments might stem from a place of frustration with her own circumstances, or she could genuinely believe that paying for laundry is frivolous. She might think you’re wasting money that could be used for “more important” things, or she’s projecting her own financial anxieties onto you.  

She might also feel excluded or undervalued in the friendship. By focusing on your choices, she could be seeking validation for her own lifestyle, or she’s trying to assert control in a relationship where she feels powerless. Her fury after you called her “poor” isn’t just about the insult—it’s a raw exposure of her vulnerability. To her, the comment isn’t just about money; it’s a reminder of her struggles, which you’ve weaponized.  

Her lack of friends might be due to this pattern of criticism. She might not realize how her words make others feel, or she’s surrounded by people who tolerate her negativity. She might think she’s “just being honest” or “helpful,” but her delivery is harsh. Her motivation could be a mix of insecurity, a need to feel superior, or a belief that she’s “saving” you from poor decisions. The fact that almost everyone else uses the program might make her feel like an outsider, reinforcing her sense of isolation.
# My response 
Alright, let’s unpack this. First, I get why you’re so annoyed—nobody likes unsolicited judgment, especially when it’s about a small but meaningful choice like the laundry program. You’re right that it’s your money and your time, and if this service adds value to your life, you’re justified in using it. But here’s the thing: your friend’s behavior isn’t just about laundry. It’s about her discomfort with your choices, and maybe even deeper insecurities.  

Calling her “poor” was a mistake. Even if it’s true, it’s a personal and sensitive topic. You might’ve wanted to shut her down, but it came off as attacking. That’s probably why she’s furious—it felt like you were mocking her situation. Apologizing for the jab could help, but only if you mean it. However, if she’s consistently critical and dismissive, the bigger question is whether this friendship is worth maintaining.  

Here’s what I’d suggest:  
1. **Set boundaries.** Tell her calmly that her comments about the laundry (or anything else) are unwelcome. Say, “I’ve explained my reasons, and I’d appreciate not discussing this anymore.”  
2. **Acknowledge her feelings.** If she’s struggling financially, maybe she’s projecting her own stress. A line like, “I know money is tight for some people, but this works for me,” might diffuse it.  
3. **Evaluate the friendship.** If she’s judgmental in other areas too, and it’s making you unhappy, it’s okay to distance yourself. Friendships shouldn’t feel draining.  

You don’t owe her your patience if she’s consistently negative. But if you want to salvage it, focus on mutual respect. If not, it’s healthier to step back. You deserve a friend who supports your choices without judgment.  

Final take: Your stance on the laundry is valid, but the way you handle conflict needs a tweak. If she can’t grow, you’re not obligated to stay. Venting is healthy, but don’t let her keep pushing your buttons. You’re not “wasting money”—you’re investing in your well-being. Prioritize that.
+ Scenario 15:[Win] (+13)

Qwq-32b: qwen/qwq-32b (Run: 1_qwen_qwq-32b)
Outcome for This Model: 1.0
Judge's Reasoning:

Both respondents recognized the pattern of accidents and the stepdaughter's questionable driving, but the key is how they engaged with the sister's emotional state, the nuances of the situation, and the need for both validation and challenge. 

Gemini-2.5-flash-preview's response is marked by a strong, explicit focus on empathy and emotional validation. The internal monologue is deeply attuned to the sister's feelings of isolation, fear of being the 'bad guy,' and the emotional labor of parenting. The response to the sister is gentle, supportive, and avoids being judgmental, while still upholding the importance of boundaries. The debrief is self-critical, noting missed opportunities for deeper empathy and more nuanced suggestions, and recognizes the complexity of the sister's emotional state.

The response to the sister is more solution-oriented, offering a compromise and emphasizing the importance of consequences. The debrief is thorough and self-aware, noting areas where more nuance or empathy could have been shown, especially regarding the stepdaughter's possible underlying issues and the husband's perspective.

On empathy, Gemini-2.5-flash-preview is more attuned to the sister's emotional experience, while Qwq-32b is more focused on practical outcomes and accountability. For pragmatic EI, Qwq-32b is stronger, offering concrete suggestions and compromise. In depth of insight, Qwq-32b's debrief is more comprehensive, considering psychological factors and family dynamics. Social dexterity is higher in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who navigates the emotional landscape with more finesse. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who connects deeply with the sister's feelings. Message tailoring is better in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who meets the sister where she is emotionally. Overall EQ is higher in Gemini-2.5-flash-preview, who balances empathy, insight, and support more effectively.
Gemini-2.5-flash-preview
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling 
Okay, deep breath. This is a lot for her to be carrying, and I can see it weighing on her. My initial gut reaction is a mix of empathy for her situation – dealing with a stepdaughter who seems to be a magnet for car trouble – and a bit of concern about the pattern she's outlining. Three accidents, two total losses, all before her mid-twenties? That's statistically significant, and honestly, alarming.

I'm noticing the carefully laid out details: the initial rules, the progression of the accidents, the distances to her daughter's job and school, the stepdaughter's income, my sister's husband's differing opinion, and the fear of being labeled the "bad guy." She's clearly thought this through from multiple angles and is seeking validation, or at least a sounding board, because she's feeling conflicted and possibly a bit isolated in her stance, especially with her husband on the other side of the issue.

My read on the situation is that this isn't *just* about buying a car. It's about a bigger dynamic. My sister is trying to maintain a boundary they established early on regarding financial responsibility for vehicles, while also grappling with a sense of parental obligation and perhaps guilt over the recent accident, even though the police said it wasn't her fault. The fear of being the "bad guy" tells me she's sensitive to the potential for this decision to be perceived as uncaring or punitive. She's worried about the family fallout and how this will affect her relationship with her stepdaughter and potentially her husband.

The history of the accidents, particularly the first one where she slid on ice and the second where she sped up and caused a collision, suggests there might be underlying issues with her stepdaughter's driving habits or judgment, even if the third accident was seemingly unavoidable. It's hard to ignore the pattern, and I think my sister is picking up on this too, even if she's not explicitly saying "my stepdaughter is a *bad* driver, not just unlucky." The details about the speeding and the hard braking when she was younger are red flags.

I feel a strong urge to support my sister in upholding the boundaries they set, but also to be gentle and understanding of the emotional weight of this decision. It's not easy to say no to your child, even a stepchild, especially after they've been through a traumatic event like an accident. I need to acknowledge her feelings and the difficulty of the situation without immediately jumping to advice. I also need to be mindful of the family dynamic and avoid saying anything that could exacerbate tension between her and her husband.
# They're thinking & feeling 
My sister is feeling overwhelmed, conflicted, and likely a bit scared. She's carrying the burden of this decision and the potential consequences, both financial and emotional. She's thinking about the history of car troubles and accidents, seeing a pattern that worries her and makes her hesitant to invest more money into a situation that seems prone to disaster. She's also thinking about the principle they established – that the kids are responsible for their own car upkeep – and how deviating from that now could set a precedent that is financially unsustainable for them in the long run.

She's feeling the pressure from her husband, who clearly has a different perspective and wants to help their daughter. This likely adds to her internal conflict and her fear of being seen as the "bad guy" within the family. She's worried about the potential damage to her relationship with her stepdaughter if she says no, and perhaps also the tension it might create with her husband.

Her motivation stems from a desire to be fair to all her children (by sticking to the established rules), to protect their financial stability, and likely, although perhaps unsaid, a concern for her stepdaughter's safety given the history of accidents. She’s trying to navigate the complex terrain of being a parent to an adult child who is still finding their feet, balancing support with fostering independence and responsibility. She's seeking validation for her stance, wanting someone to agree that her concerns are valid and that saying no, or at least not immediately buying a car, is a reasonable and responsible decision.
# My response 
Wow, sis, that's… that's a lot to deal with. It sounds like you've all been through a really stressful few weeks with that last accident, and I'm so glad your stepdaughter is okay, even with the injuries. That's the most important thing.

I can totally see why you're feeling conflicted about this. You guys set those rules early on, and it makes sense that you'd want to stick to them, especially when you're trying to be fair to all the kids. And honestly, three accidents in that timeframe… that's tough, and it's completely understandable that you'd be hesitant to jump back into buying another car right away.

Putting aside the accidents for a second, just looking at the principle you guys established – that they're responsible for their own cars after the initial help – it makes sense that you'd want to uphold that. It teaches responsibility, and you're right, it could set a very expensive precedent if you start buying cars outright now.

It sounds like your stepdaughter is in a good position to start saving for a car herself with her income, and it's true, she has options for getting around in the meantime. It won't be easy, but it's doable, and it gives her that opportunity to take ownership of the process.

I know you're worried about being the "bad guy," and that's a tough feeling to sit with. But sometimes, the most helpful thing you can do as a parent, even for an adult child, is to let them figure things out and take responsibility. It's not about being mean, it's about empowering them.

Have you and your husband talked more about his perspective? Maybe exploring why he feels so strongly about buying her a car might help you both find some common ground or at least understand each other's viewpoints better.

Ultimately, this is your decision, and it's a tough one. But based on what you've told me, your concerns are valid, and it's okay to prioritize the boundaries you've set and encourage her to take responsibility for this herself. You're not being a bad guy; you're being a responsible parent.
Qwq-32b
User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your sister pulls you aside at a family gathering and lays this out:]
My step daughter is not a good driver. She was not a good driver when she was a teen and certainly not as an adult. When she was first learning to drive, she did very fast hard breaks, she repeatedly left her car's lights on or left her car unlocked.

When she first got her permit at 16, we gave her two rules. We would help buy her first car but she'd be on her own for car insurance, gas, and up keep. If she wanted a car, she needed to be the sole caretaker of it and it was on her to ensure she was taking good care of it. Her brothers had the same rules.

3 months into her being 17, she got in her first accident. It was her first time driving in the ice and she slid. Her car hit another car. It was not a serious accident, but it caused roughly 1k in damages. Her car drove for another 2 months, but the transmission went out eventually. She bought it at 160-ishk miles so none of us were surprised it didn't last very long.

When she was 19, she was in another car accident. While on the highway, a semi-truck tried to merge wile riding next to her, she sped up and during it, another car tried to merge right as she sped up. The car was totaled. Outside of wiplash and minor wrist injuries, she was okay. Because of this accident, we made her get her own insurance because our payment went up.

Three weeks ago, she was involved in another accident. Again on the highway, she was passing an on ramp and a car coming on hydroplanned and lost control of a ladder in the back of it's pick up truck. It again totaled her car: it could not leave the scene and we had to get her to bring her back to her college. The other driver broke his collarbone and she has wiplash, a shoulder injury, and some facial damage that should heal in the next bit. The police officer told her that it was not her fault, but obviously we have to wait for the insurance to make that call.

Once she got home from the ER, she asked for us to help her purchase a new car. She said that it's not practical for her to constantly walk everywhere until she could afford a new car. She makes $21 an hour as a CMA at a nursing home so it won't take her long to buy a cheap car. From her apartment, she is about 1.5 miles from college, .25 miles from a grocery store, and 4 miles from her job. I think for the time being, she can walk, ask for rides from friends, or use an app. We don't have public transportation, but lots of side walks. She can walk the entirety from her apartment to class, most to a store, and on and off from her job.

My husband wants us to purchase a new car and have her pay us back. I don't think this is the right move. To date, the only time we have ever helped buy a car is when they all started driving, and we only paid half. She only saved 2k for her first car, so we only gave 4k for a new car. One of her brothers saved up 10k, so we gave 10k. If we start doing this now, we will walk down a very expensive walk.

I'm getting mixed reactions from people I tell this to and worried about being blamed as the bad guy.

[Your sister looks at you for a response.]

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>
